text:
ROBYN: And with us today,
we have Avril Levasseur, who

will be introducing Kristen. I said that so many times,
really great in practice. And then got to it
and I stumbled over.

Avril, I'm so sorry. Avril is an associate engineer
at Point Energy Innovations, an MEP consulting
firm, specialized

in highly cost effective net
zero energy and sustainable buildings. She's a Stanford and
McGill University alum.

And she spearheads decarbonize
building designs across the US, and has been instrumental
in fostering decarbonization

education at Stanford. Avril is going to be involved
with the virtual online workshop on November 7 and 8.

And is here to
introduce Kristen. And later, she'll be saying a
little bit about the workshop. Avril, thanks so much for
being here with us today.

And please take it away. AVRIL LEVASSEUR:
Thanks so much, Robin. And that was very close.

So thank you. Yeah. So I am actually the
program coordinator for the Stanford Building
Decarbonization Learning

Accelerator. And we're putting on this event
along with Robin and her team. So the BDLA, as we
call it, provides

free teaching resources for
building decarbonization. It's all the resources are
prepared by industry experts,

Kristen being one of them. And we also provide
guidance and assistance to professors who are
teaching the material,

as well as hosting
events like this one, like the workshop
coming up in November and several other events.

So Kristen is one
of our collaborators and has really been
the biggest contributor to the embodied carbon
content on our website.

She's also kind enough to
often speak for us at classes and events like this one. So thank you again, Kristen.

We always appreciate it. She's a leading expert in
embodied carbon and buildings. And we're so excited that
she's able to join us today.

So to give you a little
more background about her, she's an associate director
of the San Francisco office of Atelier Ten, which is
a leading environmental design

firm with offices
around the world. She runs their carbon
management practice, providing big picture guidance
for innovative materials

on the building scale. She's also involved
in large scale master plans and other
detailed analysis

like daylight optimization
and shading control. She's successfully
led some of the firm's most ambitious and
complex projects,

including the new NVIDIA
campus in Santa Clara, the San Francisco Giants Mission
Rock development,

and is currently working
on the California College of Arts in San Francisco
to develop a carbon neutral

unified campus. She's also an
experienced teacher, which I've seen firsthand, and
has taught architectural design

and environmental
systems and controls at the University of
Oregon, as well as many lectures all
over the country.

So with what I'm sure
is a very busy schedule, we're so lucky that she
was able to join us today. So thank you so much, Kristen.
And I'll hand it over to you. KRISTEN DISTEFANO: OK. Great Thanks, Avril.

and then as Robin
mentioned, we'll leave some time at
the end for questions. So if you have any, please
put them in the chat,

and we'll come back to
them all at the end. So I thought I would start
off by just telling you

a little bit more about
who we are as Atelier Ten. We're a group of sustainability
consultants, energy analysts,

and lighting designers. Many of us are
trained as architects, some is building science,
mechanical engineers,

ecologists. So we have a pretty
broad background. We have offices, as Avril
mentioned, all over the world.

So we have 10 global offices. We are founded in London. And then we have three
offices here in the US,

in New York, New Haven,
and San Francisco. And our work and the
way we approach projects

is really with the design
from first principles. And when I say that, I
mean we look to really

have our buildings passively do
more and using active systems

to do as little as possible. So we're always looking to
understand what opportunities

our local climates,
local contexts present, our building types. And we work on all sorts
of different building

types at different scales
all over the world. So it keeps things really
interesting in terms

of the role that we play
on different projects. And we really touch
subjects across all aspects

of sustainability. So whether it's working with
architects to refine building

massing and optimize facades. We might be looking at water
cycles within buildings

and master plans to see
how we could use less. We do a fair amount
of resilience

planning and looking at
the ways that that overlaps with resource conservation.

And then a whole host of
other things, including detailed building energy
simulation to look

for ways to reduce energy use. And then a real focus
on healthy buildings. So full list there.

I won't read through it. And then as I mentioned, we have
all sorts of different project

types all over the world. I've just put a few up here,
but we have been recently

lucky enough to be involved and
work on the Obama Presidential Center.

We worked on the
Uber headquarters here in San Francisco,
which has a really

innovative double skin,
naturally ventilated facade. We've got museum projects
and airport projects,

medical office buildings. So lots of different
building types. And I think we
recognize that each

of these different projects
requires a really different approach to sustainability.

So it's something that we
explore on all of our work.

So today, as Avril mentioned,
I lead our US-wide carbon

practice for Atelier Ten. And I'd say, it has
been the area that we have been really putting
a lot of our efforts

and focus on all projects. We all understand the climate
emergency that we're in.

But I think the window of time
for us to really have an impact is getting much smaller.

So we have seven years
left to avert the worst impacts of climate change. And when I think about
this, I think about the fact

that this really means the
projects that we are beginning to work on today are the ones--

we really need to be solving
these issues of getting carbon out of our buildings, not
in seven years, but now.

And we've really
seen our industry is very capable of changing. The change that I have seen in
practice over the last 15 to 20

years has been very rapid and
pretty advanced and moving

quickly. But we need to keep
going and we need to keep going faster,
especially when it comes

to reducing carbon emissions. And I think in some
fields, we sometimes

see a hope that we can
still have carbon emissions

and we can offset them. And we will kind of get
to an acceptable place in terms of 0 carbon.

But I think what
we really advocate for is, of course,
offsets are not

some sort of golden solution. We really need to be
aiming for fewer emissions. We really need to be
aiming for zero emissions.

It's not quite possible in
the current design world to have zero emissions
related to our building materials or the
operations of our building,

but it should be what
we're aiming for.

And our building-related
carbon emissions can come from a lot
of different places. We have transportation
for the folks that

are coming to and
from our buildings, who live in our buildings. There's an interesting
shift happening as we really

expand our electrical vehicle
charging infrastructure that that energy use to
transport people from one place

to another is now part of
our buildings energy demand, rather than an external source
with fuel combustion vehicles.

So transportation is a big one. Within operations
or the carbon we

use to just run and power our
buildings, we have electricity, we have natural
gas in some cases,

although getting to be less and
less, especially in California. We have refrigerants,
which can have

a really significant
greenhouse gas impact coming from our mechanical systems.

And then the water and the
waste that we use and produce within our buildings, also,
have a carbon footprint.

On the materials side,
there's an embodied carbon, which means all
of the carbon that

was used to create transport,
install, and replace, and then

dispose of, the materials
on our projects, our industry has become really
well-versed, I would say,

in looking at embodied carbon
reductions for our buildings structural systems and
our buildings envelopes.

But we are less
well-versed in looking at the embodied
carbon associated

with the site of our building or
that infrastructure that serves our building or the interior
finishes that are often changed

within a building, our
mechanical, electrical, and plumbing systems, or even
the potential for landscapes

to sequester carbon. So there's a huge host
of things that contribute

to building carbon emissions. And it's also a huge
opportunity for us to influence carbon reductions
and eliminate carbon
in each of these key areas. So I'm just going to go to the--

one moment for
changing slides here.  So on all of our
projects, one thing

that we feel really
strongly about looking at is developing a path
to carbon neutrality.

What would it take to get this
building or this master plan to zero carbon? And when we say zero
carbon, I mean zero carbon

in terms of operations
and zero carbon in terms of embodied carbon.

So I like to put up this pathway
because I think it really speaks to the way that we
prioritize and approach

this kind of necessity
of getting to zero. So we start on the left
with passive strategies.

What can we do to leverage
the local climate? What can the building form
and can the building skin

do to use less energy? How do we orient the building? How do we design our envelope
based on the climate?

How do we design our envelope
to open to the exterior? And what benefits
can that provide us in terms of energy use?

Then, after we're optimizing
for passive strategies, then we're looking
at active strategies having to do with how we
condition the buildings, how

we light our buildings,
and all of the equipment that we house within them.

We're also looking to
optimize the plant. And when I say
that, I mean, we're

looking to optimize how we
condition our buildings, whether there's an
opportunity to capture heat,

can we use shared thermal
plants between buildings of different types and I'll talk
about that a little bit more

later. And only after all
of that has been optimized should we really be
looking at renewable energy

and how we meet our demands. So we want to drive it down
as far as possible, then look at renewable energy.

And that is either on our site. Can we put photovoltaic
panels on our building?

Can we integrate them
into the building skin? Or it can be off site. If we have a site
constrained project,

there are ways that we can
invest in off site renewable energy to offset our demand.

We're also looking at
reducing embodied carbon on all of our projects. And I'll talk a little
bit more about that later.

And then we've been doing
a significant amount of work looking at the site and
the area beyond our projects

as well. So I think one of the things
that I just wanted to highlight

is that we talked about
all those sources of carbon emissions. I would say, in today's
design practice,

at least at the building scale,
in terms of building design teams, a lot of the leading
definitions of zero carbon

are really just focused
on operational energy use

to use to power the
building, and then embodied carbon of
structure and envelope. And we're leaving out a whole
host of other contributors.

So we are very strong
advocates for saying, we may not know how to
really accurately quantify

all of these other pieces, but
we shouldn't leave them out. We should be using best
practices and references

to make sure that
we're including a really holistic
look at the carbon emissions of our buildings
and not ignoring key pieces.

So there are a few
topics that I just want to talk through
today, starting

with operational carbon and
going to embodied carbon. And there are a
number of case studies

I'm just going to use
for each of these. So the first topic
that we really see is as instrumental
in our zero carbon future

is the advancement of our
electric grids to get cleaner. And in order to take
advantage of that,

the movement of our buildings
to all electric buildings, eliminating natural gas
within the building itself.

And so we've seen in
California, specifically

in Northern California,
we're seeing a lot of ordinances
passed locally to prohibit natural
gas in new buildings.

And that's generally
prohibiting natural gas for heating and
domestic hot water uses.

We're seeing more--
beginning to see it more for laboratory buildings,
commercial kitchens, and some

of those harder
to electrify uses. But the whole reason
behind this is that we have a pretty clean
electric grid in California.

Meaning that it has
a significant amount of renewable energy
content powering it.

But that renewable energy and
the cleanliness of our grid really varies from hour to hour.

So while we used to,
I'd say, in the past, we used to look at energy
use of our buildings

on an annual basis, we
are starting much more to look at how our buildings
use energy on an hour

by hour basis. And also, compare
that to what the grid emissions of our local
grid is for every hour.

And so we're not only trying
to overall reduce our energy demand, but we're also
really specifically trying

to reduce that demand
during the times when the grid is the dirtiest.

And so that's generally
happening in California.

It's happening in
the late afternoon when we stop producing renewable
energy during the middle of the day coming from solar.

And we have a
significant increase in demand in the afternoon.

So one of the projects I wanted
to start with that really begins to focus on how do we
not only drive down our energy

demand, but how do we begin to
control the times at which we use energy, is this project
designed by Studio Gang.

It's the California
College of Arts. Avril mentioned this
during the intro.

It's an arts campus, located
here in San Francisco. And it's a new project located
adjacent to an existing

building. And I'll just show
you this image here. So the existing college is
within an old bus terminal.

And they had an empty
back lot behind it, that they were looking to
build their new campus on.

And this one was a really
unique project because we had-- the client come
to us and say, we

want to know what
it takes to get to a carbon neutral project. So we started
where we usually do

on projects, which
was look at what are the passive opportunities
for this type of program.

And this really started with a
programming and space planning exercise to say, for all of
the different types of spaces

in this project, which
need to be conditioned? Which need to be indoors?

Can we accommodate some of this
programmatic element outdoors? And it was actually
something the college was

interested in doing because
their existing campus had a lot of outdoor program use. So we started to say it will
save us energy to lump together

programs that have
similar needs for lighting and similar needs for
thermal conditioning.

And that way, we
can be really loose about our thermal conditioning
in some locations,

and then provide use
energy to really regulate thermal conditions in the
areas where we need to.

I'd say the other
thing interesting thing about this project was
it's an art school.

So it has a lot of
heavy making spaces. And we knew pretty well how
a typical academic building

in Northern California
uses energy. We really didn't
have any idea how this building would use energy.
It has kilns. It has a glass-making equipment. It has a foundry.

It has textile production. So we spent a significant
amount of time

speaking with all of
the leads of the studios within this college
to understand

how their spaces were used,
what type of equipment do they have in there. And we did some early
stage energy analysis

to really identify what
were the energy drivers for this particular project.

I don't know if you
can see my cursor here, but you see this pie chart. Everything in blue and pink in
this kind of inner gray ring,

that's all of the
energy use that's coming from the equipment in the shops. So over 60% of this
building's energy use

had nothing to do with how
the building was designed. And this was a
really key insight

because it told us that we, one,
needed to design the building to be as efficient as possible.

But in addition
to doing that, we needed to collaborate
with all of the studios to understand how we
could gain efficiency

in each of those key
areas while still making those spaces really
usable for the students

and their academic programs. This caused us to have
a lot of conversations about specifically glass-making.

They weigh the types of fuel
they use for glass-making. So it was quite a
different conversation

because of the
building's energy use than it may have been on a
typical academic building.

So I just say all that to
say it is really important and was really important
on this project

to understand what
were the energy drivers to know really where
we needed to focus our design efforts.

But if we're going
for carbon neutrality, we still need to make the
design as efficient as possible

even if a lot of that energy
use is driven by equipment. So some of the things that we
were looking at in this project

was there was a ground
level plinth that housed a lot of the
heavy making equipment. And then the classrooms
could be much lighter, much

thinner structures that
allow daylight throughout, that allow cross-ventilation,
that could be night

flushed in order to
cool down thermal mass inside these spaces
at night, and then

close windows during the day to
kind of keep that cool inside. You'll see exterior walkways
wrapping these buildings.

These were really key for
a programmatic element to kind of get visual connection
between students moving

between different buildings. But they also provide really
great overhang and shading

on hard to shade
southwest facades. So there's kind of
dual purpose to a lot

of the things you're seeing. This is also a hybrid structure. So these small pavilions
are made out of mass timber.

Our team pursued and won a grant
through the state of California for the mass timber design.

So it was a really,
really great project in terms of driving down
operational energy use.

And then embodied
energy as well. So the other thing
that we looked at then

after really trying to
hone in on a passive design strategy for the
project was to look

at how much renewable energy
we could produce on site. So a lot of this
building's footprint

was really taken up by
usable program space. So within the new building, we
had pretty limited opportunity

for on-site PV. But we had a lot of opportunity
for it using the existing

building rooftop. So there was a
significant exploration to understand what the structure
of the existing building

support this, and
how could we really leverage all of that
valuable roof real estate

to produce as much
energy as possible. Another aspect of this
project, which I won't

get into in a lot of detail. But the project is planning
to have a microgrid.

Meaning that it has a series
of electrical infrastructure that connects renewable
energy generation on site

to on-site storage
back to the grid. And it has the ability to island
or disconnect from the grid

and still maintain some
electrical function without connection to the grid.

This was really
important for the college because they saw a microgrid as
a flexible infrastructure that

would enable them to
integrate different renewable technologies that
may not be ready now,

but may become
ready in the future. And this aspect of that was
important for their educational

curriculum, and to really use
the building as a laboratory to say, we're not only producing
a lot of renewable energy,

but we're going to
use it in the smartest way possible at the
smartest times possible.

So we did a fair
amount of study looking at not only how much
demand our building had,

but when that demand
was happening. And for the times when we were
producing more energy than

we needed, could we store
that and use it later in the day to offset some of
those peak grid emission times.

So really interesting project. It was one that kind of
changed the way we even did

our analysis in
order to get at some of these more complex issues. And so it's one of the reasons
I wanted to share right here.

I'd say the other thing that
we've been really focused on,

and we've seen as one of
the most rapidly advancing pieces of what we do is
an emphasis on reducing

and designing to ultimately
eliminate embodied carbon. So as I mentioned before,
embodied carbon is

all of the carbon used to
basically extract manufacture,

deliver materials that we use in
our buildings and our projects. And when we're looking at the
projection of new construction,

coming in the next 10 years,
20 years, the largest portion of the carbon coming from
that new construction

is coming upfront
with the materials that we use to build
those buildings. And so when we are
really beginning

to talk about how do we
avoid critical global tipping points, a lot of our
emphasis, yes, we

need to be on
operational carbon, but equally, or even
more so, we need to be focused on
embodied carbon.

So this is just a diagram of
all of those life cycles stages

of a material, starting
with extraction, ending with end of
life and assumptions

about how that material
may be disposed of. And then you may
hear a lot of terms

or you may already be experts
in a lot of these terms about essentially which
stages of a material

we may be talking about. So you may hear cradle to gate. Meaning, we're really just
talking about those product

first product stage emissions. You may hear up front carbon. Meaning all the emissions that
happen before that material

goes into the building. But typically, I think
we're talking more and more

and should be talking more
about whole life emissions. And that's cradle to grave. So that's measurements
about how much carbon

that material was used
to produce that material and manufacture it. Estimates about how much was
used to transport it and put it

into place in the
building, as well as how many times we
think it will be replaced in the life of the building.

And then broad assumptions about
that replacement as well as what will happen at
the end of its life.

But it's not enough
for us to just quantify

this and understand
our material cycles. We really need to put this
into actionable reduction

opportunities within our design. So we can use a tool called
a whole building lifecycle

but an LCA is not very accurate
in the beginning of a project when we don't have a design yet.

We may not have even a
structural system yet, but it's at the
beginning of a project

where we have the biggest impact
to reduce embodied carbon. We could decide to
reuse a building

instead of building one new. We could decide on a
structural system that has a significant impact
on reduced embodied carbon

and material efficiency. And so it's a bit of an
interesting challenge when

the tools that we have to
evaluate embodied carbon are very accurate when all
the decisions have been made.

So we need to be
a lot more nimble. And we need to make smart
decisions up front based

on high level analysis,
based on experience, and based on things
that kind of get

us moving in the right direction
in terms of embodied carbon reductions.

And there's a lot
of different ways we could reduce embodied carbon. I would say the
best and the thing that we should always be seeking
to do is to simply use less.

So that may be smarter
structural systems. That may be not building
a building from scratch

and maintaining structural
systems for reuse. It could be picking
better materials.

So that could be subbing out
a different insulation type or selecting a different
structural system.

Or it could be looking
once even we've decided on what material we're
using, looking for the best product that has the lowest
embodied carbon footprint.

And a lot of our work and
a lot of our conversations,

when we're talking about
low carbon structure, often, mass timber
comes up as being

synonymous with low
embodied carbon. And so we were curious
in terms of if we were--

there's a lot of
different ways that we can design building structure. Broadly, we've
done some studies.

These are based on US wide
averages of a steel frame structure versus a concrete
structure versus a mass timber

structure. And I think the question
of which is more efficient,

and if you highly optimized
concrete or steel based on today's optimization options,
or even based on what we see

will happen in the future,
kindd of which of these options is best? Is timber still lower
embodied carbon option?

And so these are all
based on US averages. So I should say these
results would vary depending on location globally,
even depending on location

in the United States. But generally, what we found
was that in today's market,

timber is still better
from a carbon perspective, but only if it is
sustainably harvested.

And so we could probably have
another entire five webinars

on sustainably harvested timber. But just to call out
here that the bars

you're seeing on the right
represent a mass timber building. Those hatched areas
represent the benefit

that we get from the
carbon that is locked into the structure,
the carbon that

has been sequestered by those
trees when they were living. So we are showing
those and demonstrating

those in these
reductions because if we have a sustainably
harvested timber building,

we can take credit for the
fact that that carbon is locked into the material.

If that timber is not
sustainably harvested, you see that these
bars begin to look

very similar to the steel
and the concrete structures in terms of carbon emissions.

So sustainable harvesting,
critically important. And then in addition to
those early conversations

about what type of
structural system, there are some carbon
reduction opportunities

that we've seen that they
hold true across the board. They are things we should
always be looking at.

We should always be looking
at concrete optimization. We should be looking at
our steel procurement. And is that steel
coming from regions

where we have clean
grids that are being used to power the
manufacturing plants,
making those steel? Rebar, same situation as steel.

Our interior finishes
become really important because you're
very often switched out

in a building. So while the upfront
carbon of your building

may be predominantly
within the structure, those interior
finishes are going to be changed out multiple
times during that building's

lifespan. And it means when we're
looking at the holistic carbon, they have a big impact. Insulation matters.

Facade materials matter. So we just like to
show these because we don't need to do any analysis
to know that these are going

to be big drivers
and to start to have early conversations about
them with our design teams.

Here's an example
of a project, where we were looking at different
concrete optimization

for different types of concrete
and applications of concrete within a project. I would say same thing here.

One of the biggest
things we can do is get your clients and
structural engineers

and architectural design teams
in the room in the beginning, if you have a
contractor on board, also the contractor
having these conversations

about all the different
concrete mixes on a project. Because sometimes, we
can make schedule changes

to get lower concrete options. Sometimes it's
different admixtures.

But there can be
different approaches to really optimize and
drive down our carbon emissions of our concrete.

And a lot of times,
those conversations should happen very early on
because they may not add cost,

but some may add time. Or they may not
add time and we can do this in a really smart
way, where we're kind

of hitting those reductions. But the conversation
has to happen early.

Then the next thing
we generally do after looking at these
big ticket items, looking at concrete,
we will start

to do an LCA or a
life cycle assessment later in the project to
understand what are the carbon

drivers for this
particular project, and where do we
focus our effort. We also begin to then test
carbon impact reduction

measures. So on the left, you see
a building profile that's looking at basically breaks
down how much of that

embodied carbon is
coming from foundation versus parking in this
case, versus structure,

versus building
skin and interiors. And then it further
breaks that down so we can see what are those
main drivers here.

In this case, concrete
and steel are huge, but also flooring and tile
are big within interiors

because of how often
they're replaced.  So we recently
worked on a project.

This is a building
designed by SOM. It's the new San Mateo
County headquarters.

We'll be the first net
zero energy civic building, constructed with mass
timber in the US. And this project
achieved an 85% reduction

in structural embodied carbon
versus a typical baseline

project. And this was really
coming from-- so this was SOM and their
internal structural team.

Not only from the fact
that it was a mass timber project sustainably
harvested, but also

from the fact that
they were involved in a lot of material
optimizations

for their structural
system throughout. So both the use
less and use better materials definitely
applied in this case.

But I think one
thing I mentioned

before was that if
we really are going to limit our embodied
carbon footprint,

it's not just going to be
through designing better new construction. We really have to take a
serious look at opportunities

for building reuse, and should
be reusing buildings more often

to the greatest extent
possible and really maintaining all of that embodied
carbon that's already

locked into a structure. So this is a project that
our East Coast team recently

worked on.  It was a reskinning of an
existing building structure.

You can see here the
breakdown of embodied carbon for a similar baseline building.

So this is if we were to
construct that building from scratch today, what
would its embodied carbon

footprint look like? You see a significant
amount coming from the structure, specifically
steel meta deck and steel

framing. And then it's also
a significant amount

coming from curtainwall
and then interiors. But really, looking at
this huge structural piece

and looking at the
opportunities that there are in reusing that
structure to reduce

embodied carbon over a
new construction building. So this was an
analysis that we did

looking at if we had built that
building for new, what would its embodied carbon footprint
be versus if we designed

to renovate the building. You save over 70% in
terms of embodied carbon

just by reusing the structure. And then with additional carbon
impact reduction measures,

reduce that a little bit more. But I think the key thing here
is reuse blows any other carbon

impact reduction measures
out of the water, and is really
effective strategy.

We worked on not
a similar project, but we worked on an
adaptive reuse project

here in San Francisco. This one was with
Swig and Gensler were the design team on this one.

You can see the existing
building on the left. You can see the new building
rendering on the right.

But this was recently completed
in the last few years. So this is a project
called 633 Folsom.

There was an opportunity
when this building became vacant to do a
renovation project that

not only kind of renovated
the existing facade and improved some of the
connection to street,

but also created an
addition that really had a very strong emphasis
on health and wellness

and the employee experience
inside the building. So one of the things that the
design team was very focused on

was developing an
innovative way to reclad the building, which would help
with that improved experience.

So they wanted to bring a
significant amount of daylight into the interiors.

They wanted to
enable a lot of the-- enable views out because there
are some incredible views

from this building. But they also wanted to
do that without bringing in a lot of heat and a lot
of glare into the building.

So the design team developed
this design strategy

of these L-shaped hoods
around each of the windows.

And you can kind of
see the new envelope getting applied and then this
shot up to the existing floors

and then the new floors
being added on top. And so optimizing that fin
shape was really important.

But one of the really
interesting things out of this work was
to look at the extent

to which those fins enabled
the views to be maintained.

And so this became a really
important part of the project discussion, which was if
you didn't have the fins,

you would need, during
certain times of the year, on each facade to kind
of draw your window blinds, your interior blinds,
to prevent direct sun and glare

from coming into the building. With the added fins,
those fins blocked out

direct sun for a number
of hours and allowed you to leave the blinds up longer. And so we did an analysis
for each of the building

orientations to look at how
many additional hours could you keep the blinds up.

How did you gain that
from adding these fins? And so these are
hourly charts which look at every occupiable
hour of the year.

And then the areas in red
are showing how many hours you gain back that
you don't have

to pull your blinds
by having these hoods. And this, you can kind of
see the result of that here.

So this is a daylight mapping
within the interior floor plan,

but also the things
we're calling out here are the additional
hours that you can maintain your blinds
up, have you out by adding

the exterior fins there. And so this project
ended up, I think,

it's usually wild success story. It's a beautiful project. I love driving past it or
biking past it when I'm down

in this part of the city. But it also was one
of the largest office

leases at a time when
leasing buildings was becoming really challenging.

So I think a lot of
that attention to health and wellness and experience
of occupants really paid off

in this kind of
reinvigorated building. And I think I'd like to show
this one because it's not

all about embodied carbon. There are certainly
other benefits we get from building reuse and
some really innovative ways

that buildings can be
reused and reimagined. So we've talked all about
buildings until now.

I want to talk a
little bit about what we can say beyond the building. What are our sites,
what are our landscapes

able to contribute to the low
embodied carbon conversation.

So this is all work,
that I'm showing, that's associated with climate
positive design challenge.

So this is a group founded by
Pamela Conrad, who is formerly at CMG landscape architects.

These are all of their diagrams I can't take credit
for any of them. They are beautiful.

But we helped
Pamela and her team develop and flesh out the
Pathfinder tool, which

was an early tool for
landscape architects to evaluate the
relative embodied carbon

emissions of their projects. And I think one of the
first conversations

I had with Pamela, she said,
landscape architects have

these really-- we have a really unique set
of tools in our toolbox. We are specifying materials
that have embodied carbon

footprints, but we
are also specifying vegetation and trees and grasses
that have sequestration rates.

And so the climate
positive design challenge is really challenging the
landscape architecture

community to design projects,
which over their lifespan,

sequester more carbon
through vegetation than they emit in terms of their
initial materials.

And I think one of the
really nice ways that they've been talking about this is
to illustrate projects not

only the embodied carbon
or the holistic carbon impact of adding
more vegetation,

adding less hardscape,
but also the kind of experience of what it
means to be in that place.

And I just love these
diagrams because they show not only metrics
around carbon emitted

and carbon sequestered,
but they also show like a fundamental
shift in what it means to be in that space and
what that space feels like.

And I think the more that as-- the more nuanced we
can be and the more

that we can be talking about
these sort of co-benefits is to the design community,
the more successful

I think we'll really
be in driving down carbon impacts of our project. So that kind of brings me
to the last point, which

is it's not all about carbon. I think reducing
carbon emissions is

by far the most pressing
global issue of our time.

But there are lots
of other factors that designers and
design teams and clients

are having to balance. And so we're very interested
in the co-benefits

of lower embodied carbon, lower
operational carbon design.

Sometimes, this is
a slide we created when we were
talking about, well,

what else do you
get out of reducing embodied carbon on a building? There was a question of
do the manufacturers, who

are reducing their embodied
carbon of their products, are they also--

do they have a better
emphasis on healthy materials? Are they focusing more on that? Are you getting
kind of two for one

when you're looking for
folks who are responsibly manufacturing things and getting
healthier materials and a lower

embodied carbon? We've had a lot of
conversations about cost.

This is an area where cost
reduction and embodied carbon reduction can go hand in hand in
terms of structural efficiency.

There are
opportunities to really be strategic and efficient
in structural design, though,

should reduce cost materials
and embodied carbon.

I think the questions
of, especially when we're talking about landscape
sequestration,

can increasing the
sequestration of our landscape also have an ecological benefit
to supporting local habitats?

And then how does our
increased emphasis on reducing embodied
carbon also really

drive a change to how
we treat materials at the end of their life? So now the fact that
we are thinking more

about the end of life of our
materials, can we drive into,

I think, we hear the term
circular economy a lot. I don't know that it's always
happening in many places.

But can we drive
to a place where we are able to have a
market for reused materials?

We are designing for end of
life for certain building structures? So I think there are
all things that we
need to be headed towards.

And then I think the other
thing that we've been focused on and that the industry I think
is beginning to focus a lot more

on is the fact that
in beginning to look at the lifespan
of our materials,

and where they come from, and
how they've been extracted, and how they're
getting manufactured, and getting all of these
details and this insight

into this whole lifespan,
gives us an opportunity to look at all of the other
ecological and human health

impacts of materials. So this is the
AIA's architecture and design materials pledge.

It has a kind of
wonderful series of things that we should be
considering when we source

materials, like human health,
like social health and equity, like ecosystem health, like
the economy that we're driving.

And climate health, the one
related to carbon emissions, is just one of these. And so I think it's a good
reminder that yes, carbon

reductions, and we
need to make sure that we're also looking at
all of these other pieces.

So anyway, I think maybe
we're getting to time

so I will end there. And I really appreciate you
listening today and looking

forward to answering questions. ROBIN: Thanks so much, Kristen. It was so interesting
insightful.

And I really love how you kind
of covered it soup to nuts. Like it's not just about what
you're doing with the building,

but where the materials
are coming from and how they're being sourced
and how important that is. So thank you for that.

KRISTEN DISTEFANO: So I see the

to throw everything we have and reducing carbon emissions.

But I think there is a

So I am really optimistic about
the advancements we've seen in building decarbonization.

I think it needs to

to electrify existing buildings,
to bring renewable energy

But I think we have an

is really necessary for us to

And when I say that, I mean,

in seeking greener

to local utilities. And some of that, often,

I would say our buildings and

support that transition to

I'd say the choices we

send signals to manufacturers

to ask them to do

I think our buildings

of the industries

that our buildings connect

enough over the built

on utility grids. And I think that's

to make a change there.  See then, the next
question are there

any limitations or
disadvantages to mass timber? Yeah. It's a good question.

Mass timber is not
for every project.  There are regions where
mass timber may not

be the lowest embodied
carbon option because it's getting trucked in. And that can be hugely
carbon intensive.

So knowing your region, knowing
where your materials are coming from, knowing if
they're sustainably harvested

is a first. There are certain dimensions of
structural grids that you can

and cannot achieve
in mass timber. There are some
local jurisdictions

and fire codes may not be
comfortable with mass timber and will require things
like encapsulation,

and require you to
cover the timber. So then you're adding
more material back. So I guess the
question is it does--

one does need to be very aware
of their local context and some of the nuances around
regulations, material sourcing,

program type, and
programmatic needs to really determine
as a team if it's the right solution for a
project because it's not
a one size fits all solution.

OK. There was a question. San Francisco is a
seismic area region. Do the materials abide by the

Yes. I mean, where these
projects are being designed in seismic regions here
in San Francisco, yeah,

those structural systems
are being designed to code, to accommodate the fact that
we are in a seismic zone.
OK. Let's see.

There's a question. What are your thoughts about how

technologies to decarbonize?

Here in New York City,
relative to Local Law 97, there's a big focus,
but feels like

limited applicable solutions. Yeah. So this is a really
good question.

I'm not sure I have
a great answer to it. And for those who don't know,
Local Law 97 in New York City

is a really advanced kind of
local requirement essentially

aimed at existing
buildings and the carbon emissions of existing
buildings in New York.

And essentially, looking
at their carbon emission

intensity and kind of having
a target by which above which they will be charged for
exceeding certain carbon

emission intensities. So it is really driving
beyond building codes, focused

on efficiency and new
construction and retrofits. It really is starting
to drive and tackle

that issue of existing
buildings, which is where in terms of
our built environment, a lot of our carbon
is really tied up in.

So it's a very progressive law. And I think we'll see how
the implications play out.

But it's really trying to
incentivize building owners to do better in terms
of their building

performance and operations. So I think my hope here
is that a law like that

really does drive where we
have gaps in technology to meet those demands, kind
of drives innovation

and drives a market to
respond to some of those gaps, and beginning to--

I think it'll be a
combination of incentives to begin to
incentivize homeowners

or multifamily homeowners,
provide some funding to kind of make those retrofits.

So there's the
carrot and the stick. You get the carrot of incentives
to do the better thing when you're retrofitting.

You have the stick
through Local Law 97 to kind of penalize larger
building owners if they

do have high carbon emissions. So I hope that drives some
innovation and solution.

So kind of a non-answer,
but hopefully, those are things that are heading the

OK. Let's see. So and then the last question I

per kilogram of CO2e? OK. This is a really

We are always talking about what
the right way to do this is. And I'd love to hear
other's experience on this.

We do often estimate the
total reduction in carbon.

We don't always
estimate the price. And I think the reason for--

let's just say the other
thing we do look at is dollars invested
per carbon saved.

And so sometimes, we'll
look at that metric to say, where can
we most effectively,

if there is a premium for
some of these strategies, where can we most effectively

the largest carbon reductions. But yeah, we've been
looking into this question.

We found different
companies are-- may actually have their own

So we've seen companies use

to estimate the kind of
risk of higher carbon emissions in future holdings

We've seen some companies just

So companies that have committed
to carbon neutral operations do pay a price to
offset their carbon.

Sometimes that is a
real price that they're including in planning efforts. We've seen companies,

has an internal carbon tax. So they're using-- charging

use kind of more carbon. And that money is

So we don't often do this
